title: Pro-Pac Packaging on hunt for new CEO amid Rich Lister blues
text:
A second ASX-listed packaging company in which Rich Lister Raphael Geminder holds a large stake is on the lookout for a new chief executive amid souring trading conditions.

Pro-Pac Packaging chief executive Grant Harrod is departing, one day after a profit downgrade at the group.

Pro-Pac Packaging is chaired by former Australia Post chief executive and National Australia Bank executive Ahmed Fahour, who on Tuesday announced that headhunter firm Egon Zehnder had been entrusted to find a new boss at Pro-Pac.

Two ASX-listed packaging companies in which Rich Lister Raphael Geminder holds a large stake are now looking for a new CEO. Josh Robenstone

Mr Geminder holds 45.1 per cent of Pro-Pac through his Bennamon vehicle. Mr Geminder is the brother-in-law of Australia's richest person, Anthony Pratt, and was listed at No.53 in the latest Financial Review Rich List.

The larger ASX-listed packaging company Pact Group, in which Mr Geminder holds a 39 per cent stake, announced another profit downgrade on November 8.
description: A second ASX-listed packaging company in which Rich Lister Raphael Geminder holds the biggest stake is looking for a new CEO.
